message.content:
We start by working out the family “chains” for Raymond and for Logan.

For Raymond we have:
• “Natalie is Raymond’s ancestor.”
Looking for additional connections on that side we find:
• “Natalie is Ann’s descendant” (so Ann is an ancestor of Natalie)
• “Dennis is Ann’s ancestor” (so Dennis is an ancestor of Ann)
Thus one chain is
  Dennis → Ann → Natalie → Raymond.
This means that Raymond’s known ancestors are Natalie (and, by extension, Ann and Dennis).

For Logan we have:
• “Ronald is Logan’s ancestor.”
There is also the clue:
• “Ronald is Bradley’s descendant” (so Bradley is an ancestor of Ronald)
• “Adam is Bradley’s ancestor” (so Adam is an ancestor of Bradley)
• “Michael is Adam’s ancestor” (so Michael is an ancestor of Adam)
Thus one chain is
  Michael → Adam → Bradley → Ronald → Logan.
So Logan’s known ancestors are Ronald (and, by extension, Bradley, Adam, and Michael).

When we compare these two chains we see that the sets of names do not appear to intersect at all. There is no indication that Dennis, Ann, or Natalie are the same person as Michael, Adam, Bradley, or Ronald – nor is there any clue that someone appears as an ancestor in both chains.

Let’s check the list of options:
1. Raymond and Logan share a common descendant. – There is no evidence of any person descending from both.
2. Raymond is Logan’s descendant. – No chain shows such a link.
3. Raymond and Logan share a common ancestor. – We would need at least one person to be an ancestor of both. The two ancestry lines appear completely disjoint.
4. Raymond is Logan’s ancestor. – No chain shows that either.
5. None of the above is correct.

Because we cannot find any link (common ancestor, direct descendant relationship, or shared descendant) between Raymond’s family tree and Logan’s family tree, the correct answer is:

<ANSWER>5</ANSWER>
